page.title: 16THE MAYOR'S WEIGHING IN
page.content: {The Weighing-in}is a very old and colourful tradition of the Borough Council, which takes place every June outside the{Falcon Hotel}in the High Street. The ceremony is belived to date from{Medieval times,}but it died out in 1500 and was not revived again until 1917. The weighing machine used to take 24 stone. The present machine is a scale with a red velvet seat, suspended from an overhead dial which hangs from a large brass canopy. {The heaviest weight}ever recorded was in 1960 when{Councillor K.A.Wood weighed in at 20 stone 4 pounds. If the Mayor has gained weight over the year the mace-bearer, shouts the weight with the words{"and some more" the crowd then jeer and boo because it is said the Mayor lived well at the ratepayers expense. If weight is less, the Mayor is said to have done well.
